query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Ma dimmi, e come amico mi perdona 20 se troppa sicurtà m’allarga il freno, 21 e come amico omai meco ragiona:
22 come poté trovar dentro al tuo seno 23 loco avarizia, tra cotanto senno 24 di quanto per tua cura fosti pieno?».
query.result:
**English:**
19 But tell me, and as a friend forgive me 20 if too much boldness loosens my rein, 21 and as a friend now reason with me:
22 how could avarice find a place within your breast, 23 among so much wisdom, 24 of which through your care you were so full?
**Old English:**
19 Ac sege me, and swa ðu freond eart, forgif me 20 gif ðin ofermod ðinne brydel toðeonað, 21 and swa ðu freond nu mid me spræce:
22 hu mihte ðin sefa innan ðinum bosme 23 findan gefean, ðurh ðone miclan wisdom 24 ðe ðu ðurh ðine gime ða geworht hæfdest?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Queste parole Stazio mover fenno 26 un poco a riso pria; poscia rispuose: 27 «Ogne tuo dir d’amor m’è caro cenno.
query.result:
**English:**
25 These words made Statius smile 26 a little at first; then he replied: 27 "Every word you say about love is a dear sign to me.
**Old English:**
25 Þas word Stace seonunga bæron 26 lythwon on hleahtor; ða he eft ongan 27 andswaru secgan: "Æghwylc ðinra word 28 ðe ðu sprecen hæfst be ðam soðan lufe, 29 me is leoflic and ðin lof gebunden."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Veramente più volte appaion cose 29 che danno a dubitar falsa matera 30 per le vere ragion che son nascose.
query.result:
**English:**
28 Truly, many times things appear 29 that give false cause for doubt 30 because of the true reasons that are hidden.
**Old English:**
28 Soðlice oft gesewen bið ðæt ðing 29 ðe ðone geleafan lease gebringð 30 ðurh ða soðan gescead ðe syndon digle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 La tua dimanda tuo creder m’avvera 32 esser ch’i’ fossi avaro in l’altra vita, 33 forse per quella cerchia dov’ io era.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Your question confirms your belief 32 that I was miserly in the other life, 33 perhaps because of that circle where I was.
**Old English:**
31 ðin bøn ðin geleafa mæðeð 32 ðæt ic wæs gitsere on ðam oðrum life, 33 mægðan be ðam rince ðær ic wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Or sappi ch’avarizia fu partita 35 troppo da me, e questa dismisura 36 migliaia di lunari hanno punita.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Now know that avarice was 35 driven too far from me, and this excess 36 has been punished for thousands of moons.
**Old English:**
34 Nu ðu scealt witan ðæt ðeos unrihtwisnes wæs 35 to ðam micle fram me afyrred, and ðeos ofermæð 36 ðusenda monða ðurh ða wræce ðrowode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 E se non fosse ch’io drizzai mia cura, 38 quand’ io intesi là dove tu chiame, 39 crucciato quasi a l’umana natura:
40 ‘Per che non reggi tu, o sacra fame 41 de l’oro, l’appetito de’ mortali?’, 42 voltando sentirei le giostre grame.
query.result:
**English:**
37 And if I had not directed my attention, 38 when I heard you calling there, 39 almost angry with human nature:
40 ‘Why do you not restrain, O sacred hunger 41 for gold, the appetite of mortals?’, 42 turning back I would have felt the bitter jousts.
**Old English:**
37 And gif ic ða ne gymde mines modes, 38 ða ic ðær gehyrde ðær ðu clypodest, 39 yrre geworden neah ðære menniscan gecynde:
40 ‘Hwi ne gestillest ðu, ðu halige gytsung, 41 ðara deadlicra manna modes lust?’, 42 on bæc gewend ic ða graman gesceaft funde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Allor m’accorsi che troppo aprir l’ali 44 potean le mani a spendere, e pente’mi 45 così di quel come de li altri mali.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Then I realized that spreading my wings too much 44 could cause my hands to fail, and I repented 45 of that as well as of my other sins.
**Old English:**
43 Þa ic onfand ðæt to ðæs micle up 44 ða handa mæg ðurh ðone fleog spreotan, and ic me ðæs ongan 45 ofþincan swa ðæs oðres yfeles.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Quanti risurgeran coi crini scemi 47 per ignoranza, che di questa pecca 48 toglie ’l penter vivendo e ne li stremi!
49 E sappie che la colpa che rimbecca 50 per dritta opposizione alcun peccato, 51 con esso insieme qui suo verde secca;
52 però, s’io son tra quella gente stato 53 che piange l’avarizia, per purgarmi, 54 per lo contrario suo m’è incontrato».
query.result:
**English:**
46 How many will rise up with shorn hair 47 through ignorance, which takes away 48 the repentance for this sin while living and at the end!
49 And know that the fault which rebukes 50 a sin directly opposed to it, 51 dries up its greenness here together with it;
52 therefore, if I have been among those people 53 who weep for avarice, to purge myself, 54 I have encountered its opposite.
**Old English:**
46 Hu mænige arisað mid scearede loccum 47 ðurh unræd, ðe ðisse synne 48 ðone hreoweð forðnimð lifgende and æt ðam endum!
49 And wita ðæt ðæt leahtor ðe wiðsacað 50 ðurh rihte andsæte ænigum synne, 51 mid ðam togædere hær his grene dreogað;
52 forðy, gif ic wæs betwux ðam folce 53 ðe bewepað ðone gitsunge, ðurh ðæt ic me geclænsige, 54 ðurh ðæs andsæte me is gelimpen».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 «Or quando tu cantasti le crude armi 56 de la doppia trestizia di Giocasta», 57 disse ’l cantor de’ buccolici carmi,
58 «per quello che Clïò teco lì tasta, 59 non par che ti facesse ancor fedele 60 la fede, sanza qual ben far non basta.
query.result:
**English:**
55 "Now when you sang of the cruel arms 56 of the double sorrow of Jocasta," 57 said the singer of the bucolic songs,
58 "for what Clio there inspires in you, 59 it does not seem that faith made you faithful yet, 60 without which good deeds are not enough.
**Old English:**
55 "Nu ða ðu sunge ða heardan wæpnu 56 ðære twyfealdan tregan Giocasta," 57 cwæð se scop ðara būcendra leoða,
58 "for ðæm ðe ðe Clio ðær on tæhte, 59 ne ðuhte ðe ðæt ða gyt getreowe 60 se geleafa, butan ðæm nan man ne mæg wel gedon."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Se così è, qual sole o quai candele 62 ti stenebraron sì, che tu drizzasti 63 poscia di retro al pescator le vele?».
query.result:
**English:**
61 If this is so, what sun or what candles 62 so dimmed you that you turned 63 your sails behind the fisherman?
**Old English:**
61 Gif hit swa is, hwæt sunne oððe hwæt leoht 62 ðe forstærde swa ðæt ðu on bæc gewendest 63 ðine segl æfter ðam fiscere?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Ed elli a lui: «Tu prima m’invïasti 65 verso Parnaso a ber ne le sue grotte, 66 e prima appresso Dio m’alluminasti.
query.result:
**English:**
64 And he to him: "You first invited me 65 to Parnassus to drink at its springs, 66 and then you enlightened me next to God.
**Old English:**
64 And he to him: "Þu ær me lærðest 65 To Parnaso, þæt ic þær sceolde 66 Drincan of ðinum burnan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Facesti come quei che va di notte, 68 che porta il lume dietro e sé non giova, 69 ma dopo sé fa le persone dotte,
70 quando dicesti: ‘Secol si rinova; 71 torna giustizia e primo tempo umano, 72 e progenïe scende da ciel nova’.
query.result:
**English:**
67 You acted like someone who walks at night, 68 who carries the light behind him and does not benefit himself, 69 but makes those behind him wise,
70 when you said: ‘The age is renewed; 71 justice returns and the first human age, 72 and a new lineage descends from heaven’.
**Old English:**
67 ðu dydest swa swa se ðe on niht gæð, 68 se ðe byrð þone leoht æfter him and him sylfum ne fremað, 69 ac ða þe him æfter cumað he ða geðeahtað,
70 ða ðu cwæde: ‘Weoruld is onwended; 71 rihtwisnes cymð and ðæs formeste mannes yld, 72 and of heofenum niwe cneorisse becymð’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Per te poeta fui, per te cristiano: 74 ma perché veggi mei ciò ch’io disegno, 75 a colorare stenderò la mano.
query.result:
**English:**
73 For you I was a poet, for you a Christian: 74 but so that you may see what I am planning, 75 I will stretch out my hand to paint.
**Old English:**
73 For ðe wæs ic scop, for ðe wæs ic Cristen: 74 ac ðæt ðu geseo ðæt ic ðence, 75 ic wille hentan ða heowe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 E pria ch’io conducessi i Greci a’ fiumi 89 di Tebe poetando, ebb’ io battesmo; 90 ma per paura chiuso cristian fu’mi,
91 lungamente mostrando paganesmo; 92 e questa tepidezza il quarto cerchio 93 cerchiar mi fé più che ’l quarto centesmo.
query.result:
**English:**
88 And before I led the Greeks to the rivers 89 of Thebes in poetry, I received baptism; 90 but for fear I was a secret Christian,
91 for a long time feigning paganism; 92 and this lukewarmness made the fourth circle 93 encircle me more than the fourth hundredth.
**Old English:**
88 And ær ðam ðe ic gelædde ða Grecas to ðam flodum 89 Thebana on leoðum, ða onfeng ic fulluht; 90 ac for ðære fyrhte wæs ic cristen digol,
91 lange tide hæðenscipe feigende; 92 and ðeos laðnes min ðone feorðan hring 93 ymbclypte ma ðonne ðone feorðan hund.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Tu dunque, che levato hai il coperchio 95 che m’ascondeva quanto bene io dico, 96 mentre che del salire avem soverchio,
97 dimmi dov’ è Terrenzio nostro antico, 98 Cecilio e Plauto e Varro, se lo sai: 99 dimmi se son dannati, e in qual vico».
query.result:
**English:**
94 You then, who have lifted the lid 95 that was hiding from me how much good I speak of, 96 while we have time to spare for climbing,
97 tell me where our ancient Terence is, 98 Caecilius and Plautus and Varro, if you know: 99 tell me if they are damned, and in what circle».
**Old English:**
94 ðu ðonne, ðe ðone hrof hæfst of ðære 95 ðe me ðeahte hu micel ðæt god sie ðe ic secge, 96 ða hwile ðe we habbað ðæs stigende genog,
97 sege me hwær is Terentius ure ealde, 98 Caecilius and Plautus and Varro, gif ðu ðæt wast: 99 sege me gif ða syndon forðemde, and on hwylcum wicum».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 «Costoro e Persio e io e altri assai», 101 rispuose il duca mio, «siam con quel Greco 102 che le Muse lattar più ch’altri mai,
103 nel primo cinghio del carcere cieco; 104 spesse fïate ragioniam del monte 105 che sempre ha le nutrice nostre seco.
query.result:
**English:**
100 "These, and Persius, and I, and many others," 101 replied my leader, "are with that Greek 102 who drank more deeply of the Muses' spring than any other,
103 in the first circle of the sightless prison; 104 often we speak of the mountain 105 that always keeps our nurses with it.
**Old English:**
100 "Þas and Persius and ic and fela oðre," 101 andswarode min heretoga, "synd on ðam Greciscan 102 ðe ða Musan dranc deoplicor ðonne ænig oder,
103 on ðam forman cyninge ðæs blindan cwearternes; 104 oft we spræcon ymbe ðone munt 105 ðe symle hæfð ure fostran mid him."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Euripide v’è nosco e Antifonte, 107 Simonide, Agatone e altri piùe 108 Greci che già di lauro ornar la fronte.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Euripides is here with us, and Antiphon, 107 Simonides, Agathon, and others more, 108 Greeks who once adorned their brows with laurel.
**Old English:**
106 Euripides is her mid us and Antiphon, 107 Simonides, Agathon, and other mo, 108 Greeks ðe whilom laurel did on ðæm brede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Quivi si veggion de le genti tue 110 Antigone, Deïfile e Argia, 111 e Ismene sì trista come fue.
query.result:
**English:**
109 There are seen of your people 110 Antigone, Deiphile, and Argia, 111 and Ismene as sad as she was.
**Old English:**
109 Þær mon mæg geseon of ðinum folce 110 Antigone, Deïfile, and Argia, 111 and Ismene swiðe unblide swa heo wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Védeisi quella che mostrò Langia; 113 èvvi la figlia di Tiresia, e Teti, 114 e con le suore sue Deïdamia».
query.result:
**English:**
112 You can see her who showed Langia; 113 there is the daughter of Tiresias, and Thetis, 114 and Deidamia with her sisters.
**Old English:**
112 ðu miht ðær geseon ða ðe Langia ætywde; 113 ðær is ðæs Tiresias dohtor, and Thetis, 114 and Deidamia mid hyre sweostor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Tacevansi ambedue già li poeti, 116 di novo attenti a riguardar dintorno, 117 liberi da saliri e da pareti;
118 e già le quattro ancelle eran del giorno 119 rimase a dietro, e la quinta era al temo, 120 drizzando pur in sù l’ardente corno,
121 quando il mio duca: «Io credo ch’a lo stremo 122 le destre spalle volger ne convegna, 123 girando il monte come far solemo».
query.result:
**English:**
115 Both poets were now silent, 116 once again attentive to looking around, 117 free from climbing and from walls;
118 and already four handmaidens of the day 119 were left behind, and the fifth was at the chariot pole, 120 still raising its burning horn on high,
121 when my guide said: "I believe that at the edge 122 we must turn our right shoulders, 123 going around the mountain as we are accustomed to doing."
**Old English:**
115 Þa wæron ða begen ða scopas stille, 116 eft hira eagenaweorc ongunnon, 117 freoðoðe on stige and on staþole;
118 and wæron ða feower ðæs dæges ðenan 119 æfter faran, and seo fifte wæs on temo, 120 drihtende ða gyt ðone hatan horn,
121 ða cwæð min latteow: "Ic wene ðæt we nu 122 ða swiðran eaxle sceolon wendan, 123 ymb ðone munt faran swa we ær dydon."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Così l’usanza fu lì nostra insegna, 125 e prendemmo la via con men sospetto 126 per l’assentir di quell’ anima degna.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Thus custom was our guide there, 125 and we took our way with less suspicion 126 because of the assent of that worthy soul.
**Old English:**
124 Swa wæs ðær ðeaw ðæt us gewissode, 125 and we ða wei ongunnon wendan 126 ðurh ðæs ðegnes word ðe us ðær wel lærde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Elli givan dinanzi, e io soletto 128 di retro, e ascoltava i lor sermoni, 129 ch’a poetar mi davano intelletto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 They went in front, and I alone 128 behind, and I listened to their words, 129 which gave me the intellect to make poetry.
**Old English:**
127 Hie ða forð gewendon, and ic ana æfter, 128 and ða heora spræce hlyste, 129 ða ðe me to ðam wyrce gleawne geteodon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Dal lato onde ’l cammin nostro era chiuso, 137 cadea de l’alta roccia un liquor chiaro 138 e si spandeva per le foglie suso.
query.result:
**English:**
136 On the side where our path was blocked, 137 a clear stream fell from the high rock 138 and spread over the leaves above.
**Old English:**
136 On ðære healfe ðær ure weg wæs belocen, 137 feoll of ðære hean stan a wæter cleoru, 138 and hit tosprang ofer ða leafu ufan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Li due poeti a l’alber s’appressaro; 140 e una voce per entro le fronde 141 gridò: «Di questo cibo avrete caro».
query.result:
**English:**
139 The two poets approached the tree; 140 and a voice from within the leaves 141 cried out: "You will hold this food dear."
**Old English:**
139 Þa twegen scopas to ðam treowe eodon; 140 and of ðam leafge limpe stefne 141 cleopode and cwæð: "Þisne mete ge magon lufian."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Poi disse: «Più pensava Maria onde 143 fosser le nozze orrevoli e intere, 144 ch’a la sua bocca, ch’or per voi risponde.
query.result:
**English:**
142 Then she said: "Mary thought more about where 143 the honorable and complete wedding 144 could be, than about her own mouth, which now answers for you.
**Old English:**
142 ða cwæð heo: "Marïa ma þohte mare 143 hwær ða gifta wæron orlegh and eall, 144 ðonne ðin muð, ðe nu ðurh ðe andwyrdeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
145 E le Romane antiche, per lor bere, 146 contente furon d’acqua; e Danïello 147 dispregiò cibo e acquistò savere.
query.result:
**English:**
145 And the ancient Romans, for their drinking, 146 were content with water; and Daniel 147 scorned food and acquired knowledge.
**Old English:**
145 And ða ealdan Rómware, for heora beore, 146 wæron ðæs wætres geblissade; and Daniel 147 forhogode mete and ða ða gleawnesse geceas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
148 Lo secol primo, quant’ oro fu bello, 149 fé savorose con fame le ghiande, 150 e nettare con sete ogne ruscello.
query.result:
**English:**
148 The first age, when gold was beautiful, 149 made acorns tasty with hunger, 150 and every stream nectar with thirst.
**Old English:**
148 Se forma ða æreste, ða gold wæs god, 149 worhte ða ða acorna wynsume mid hungre, 150 and æghwylc burna beorma mid þurste.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
151 Mele e locuste furon le vivande 152 che nodriro il Batista nel diserto; 153 per ch’elli è glorïoso e tanto grande
154 quanto per lo Vangelio v’è aperto».
query.result:
**English:**
151 Honey and locusts were the food 152 that nourished the Baptist in the desert; 153 therefore he is glorious and so great
154 as is revealed to you by the Gospel.
**Old English:**
151 Hunig and gærshoppan wæron ða bigleofan 152 ðe ðone Fulluhtere on wæstenne feddon; 153 forðæm he is wuldorfull and swa micel
154 swa ðurh ðæt Godspell eow is open.
